definitions.definition: to be brave enough to do something

examples.text: She said it as loudly as she dared.
He didn’t dare (to) say what he thought.
They daren't ask for any more money.
She dared not breathe a word of it to anybody.
There was something, **dare I say it**, a little unusual about him.
I wouldn't dare go by myself.
He didn't dare (to) say what he thought.

definitions.definition: to challenge somebody to do something dangerous, difficult or embarrassing so that they can show that they are not afraid
definitions.sensetop: dare somebodydare somebody to do something

examples.text: Go on! Take it! I dare you.
Some of the older boys had dared him to do it.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody strongly not to do something

examples.text: ‘I'll tell her about it.’ ‘Don't you dare!’
Don't you dare say anything to anybody.

definitions.definition: used to show that you are angry about something that somebody has done

examples.text: How dare you talk to me like that?
How dare she imply that I was lying?

definitions.definition: used when you are saying that something is likely

examples.text: I dare say you know about it already.

wordOrigin: Old English durran, of Germanic origin; related to Gothic gadaursan, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek tharsein and Sanskrit dhṛṣ- ‘be bold’.
